WASHINGTON U.S. Vice President Joe Biden said on Friday he is not interested in serving under Democrat Hillary Clinton if she is elected president.""I'll do anything I can if Hillary's elected to help her
column2: but I don't want to remain in the administration
column3: Biden said in an interview with NBC's KBJR affiliate in Duluth
column4: Minnesota.On Thursday
column5: Politico reported that Clinton's campaign was considering Biden for secretary of state if she wins the Nov. 8 election.

1	http://reuters.com/article/us-trump-accusers-factbox-idUSKCN12S2KT	Factbox: Women who have alleged inappropriate conduct by Trump	"
At least 12 women have accused U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump of sexual advances and groping. Among his accusers are a Miss Utah beauty pageant winner
column2: a businesswoman
column3: a reporter and a receptionist. He has denied the accusations.In a 2005 video that emerged on Oct. 7
column4: Trump boasted about grabbing women by the genitals and kissing them without their consent. In a U.S. presidential debate on Oct. 9
column5: he said he was embarrassed by what he called ""locker-room talk"" but had not engaged in the conduct he described in the video. Trump has called ""absolutely false"" the allegations by several women of groping and other misconduct
column6: reported by The New York Times and other news media. At a rally this month
column7: after two more women made accusations of groping
column8: he denounced all the recent allegations by a series of women
column9: calling them fabrications and calling the women ""sick."" Following are some of the allegations against Trump: Jessica Leeds
column11: recounted in a video interview posted on The New York Times website on Oct. 12 that Trump grabbed her breasts and tried to put his hand up her skirt on a flight to New York in or around 1980 when she was a 38-year-old traveling businesswoman. In a tweet and in a later speech on Oct. 13
column12: Trump called the Times story a total fabrication.Kristin Anderson
column13: in a video posted on the website of The Washington Post on Oct. 14
column14: said Trump put his hand up her skirt in a crowded New York nightclub in the early 1990s in an unwanted advance
column15: when she had never even met him. ""He did touch my vagina through my underwear
column17: Anderson said in the video interview.Jill Harth
column18: a former Trump beauty pageant business associate
column19: filed a $125 million lawsuit in 1997 against Trump alleging that on Jan. 24
column23: Trump ""forcibly removed plaintiff to a bedroom
column24: whereupon defendant subjected plaintiff to defendant's unwanted sexual advances."" A Trump spokesperson was quoted on Oct. 7 in The New York Times as saying
column25: ""Mr. Trump denies each and every statement made by Ms. Harth."" The lawsuit was dropped in May 1997.

column1: Temple Taggart
column2: a former Miss Utah
column3: said that Trump twice kissed her on the lips in greeting while she was a contestant for the Miss USA pageant in 1997
column4: when she was 21 years old. ""What he did made me feel so uncomfortable that I ended up cutting my trip short
column5: bought my own plane ticket
column6: flew home and never spoke to him again
column7: Taggart said at an Oct. 28 press conference in Salt Lake City with her attorney
column8: Gloria Allred.Cathy Heller said that Trump in 1997 tried to kiss her during a Mother's Day brunch at Mar-A-Lago. Heller
column10: her three children and her in-laws attended the event. When she was introduced to Trump

column16: come on.' He was strong. And he grabbed me and went for my mouth and went for my lips."" She said she turned her head and Trump kissed her on the side of the mouth.

column1: Yoga instructor Karena Virginia

column10: ""This allegation lacks any merit or veracity.""Rachel Crooks
column11: formerly a receptionist at a real estate firm
column12: told The New York Times in a report published on Oct. 12   that Trump ""kissed me directly on the mouth"" in 2005 at Trump Tower in Manhattan when she was 22. In a tweet and in a later speech on Oct. 13
column13: Trump called the Times story a total fabrication.

column1: Natasha Stoynoff
column2: a reporter
column3: wrote a first-person account that described Trump kissing her without her consent in December 2005 at Mar-a-Lago while she was working on an article about him and his third wife
column4: Melania

I don't think anybody saw it but I flinched and thought: 'What is happening?'

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN12S2CV	Clinton presidential campaign hit by FBI email probe 11 days before election	"
By Mark Hosenball and Jonathan Allen
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK
WASHINGTON/NEW YORK The FBI is investigating more emails as part of a probe into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email system
column2: it said on Friday
column3: in a new twist that could damage the Democratic candidate in the 2016 presidential race.Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey said in a letter to senior lawmakers that the agency would determine whether the additional emails contained classified information
column4: adding that he did not know ""how long it will take us to complete this additional work.""The announcement came as Clinton and Republican opponent Donald Trump enter the final stretch of campaigning ahead of the Nov. 8 election. In a news conference late on Friday in Des Moines
column5: Iowa
column6: Clinton urged Comey to release more details about what the FBI was looking for in the newly discovered emails.She leads Trump in opinion polls after a bruising campaign in which she has struggled to convince voters that she is trustworthy and honest. Fresh revelations about her use of email are unlikely to assuage those concerns
column7: and questions around the FBI investigation will now likely dog her in the coming days as she campaigns across battleground states.U.S. stocks immediately fell sharply on the news
column8: but went on to partially recover.The FBI spent about a year investigating Clinton's use of the unauthorized server at her home in Chappaqua
column10: while she was U.S. secretary of state after classified government secrets were found in some of her emails. Comey said in July that while ""there is evidence of potential violations of the statutes regarding the handling of classified information
column11: our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case.""Although Comey recommended no criminal charges be brought against Clinton
column12: Trump has repeatedly said her email practices are criminal and should disqualify her for office. He seized on Friday's development at rallies in Maine and New Hampshire.""This is the biggest political scandal since Watergate
column13: and I'm sure it will be properly handled from this point forward
column14: Trump told a crowd in Lisbon
column16: all justice will be fully served
column17: he said. Supporters cheered his words and chanted
column18: ""Lock her up.""Clinton said she had learned of the newly discovered emails from news reports.

column1: I'm confident whatever they are will not change the conclusion reached in July
column2: she said. ""That's why it's incumbent upon the FBI to tell us what's going on.""WEINER

column1: Two sources close to the investigation said the latest emails were discovered not during an investigation into Clinton
column2: but rather as part of a separate probe into Anthony Weiner
column3: the estranged husband of top Clinton aide Huma Abedin.The FBI has been investigating illicit text messages allegedly sent from Weiner to a 15-year-old girl in North Carolina
column4: and found the Clinton emails on a device related to that investigation
column5: the sources said.Abedin told federal investigators in April that she used several email accounts for her work
column6: including a Yahoo email
column7: according to a summary of the interview released by the FBI in September. She said it was difficult to print from the State Department's email system so she routinely forwarded documents to her private accounts when she needed to print them out

column1: Abedin announced her separation from Weiner in August after a sex scandal similar to an earlier incident that led him to resign from the U.S. Congress.Lawyers representing Abedin did not respond to questions sent by email on Friday. Weiner did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment
column2: and he did not respond to phone calls.Hank Sheinkopf
column3: a Democratic strategist who had previously advised former President Bill Clinton but has no role with Hillary Clinton's campaign
column4: said the linking of Clinton's email woes with Weiner's sex scandals made it harder for her campaign to distinguish itself from Trump's sex scandals.""The whole campaign is now smeared with sex
column5: corruption and scandal
column6: he said. ""Nobody remembers the beginning of something
column7: they only remember the end. What are they going to remember? They're all the same: sex
column10: emails. People are going to have trouble sorting out all this information.""""EXTRAORDINARY""

column1: Clinton's campaign chairman
column2: John Podesta
column3: said it was ""extraordinary"" for the FBI to release the letter so close to the end of a hotly contested election.""The Director owes it to the American people to immediately provide the full details of what he is now examining
column4: Podesta said in a statement. ""We are confident this will not produce any conclusions different from the one the FBI reached in July."" Clinton has repeatedly apologized for using the private email server in her home instead of a government email account for her work as secretary of state from 2009 to 2013. She has said she did not knowingly send or receive classified information.While the FBI probe of new emails will likely prove a distraction to Clinton in the coming days
column5: it was unclear what impact it would have when Americans go to the polls. Election experts say about 20 percent of ballots have already been cast
column6: as more Americans vote by mail or go to the polls early.""A lot of concern about the emails has already been baked into this electoral cake I think
column8: a professor of government at Dartmouth College. ""They know she did it
column9: they know it was inappropriate and
column10: failing some sensational revelation on Nov. 6
column11: it's hard to see that it's going to make that big a difference.""Still
column13: who are facing a difficult fight to keep their majorities in both the U.S. Senate and the House of Representatives
column14: leaped to condemn Clinton.House Speaker Paul Ryan reiterated his call that the Democratic nominee be barred from briefings involving classified information until the investigation is over. Reince Priebus
column15: the head of the Republican National Committee
column16: said the FBI's decision to look into the emails shows ""how serious this discovery must be.""   Clinton did not respond to reporters' shouted questions about the news when she left her plane for a campaign stop in Cedar Rapids
column17: Iowa.U.S. stocks declined in a volatile session on Friday but partially recovered from the sharp drop spurred by the FBI announcement. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed the day down about 9 points
column19: while the benchmark 10-year Treasury note was unchanged on the day. The dollar also fell against major currencies. (Additional reporting by Susan Heavey
column20: Julia Harte and Andy Sullivan in Washington
column25: and Sam Forgione and Nate Raymond in New York; Writing by Jonathan Allen
column26: Patricia Zengerle and Emily Flitter; Editing by Jonathan Oatis

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-ryan-idUSKCN12S2BO	U.S. House Speaker Ryan renews call to suspend classified briefings for Clinton	"

WASHINGTON U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan on Friday renewed his call for U.S. intelligence officials to stop giving Hillary Clinton classified briefing typically given to presidential candidates in the wake of FBI Director James Comey's letter citing additional emails now under review.""This decision
column2: long overdue
column3: is the result of her reckless use of a private email server
column4: and her refusal to be forthcoming with federal investigators. I renew my call for the Director of National Intelligence to suspend all classified briefings for Secretary Clinton until this matter is fully resolved
column5: Ryan said in a statement referring to the former secretary of state.

column1: (Reporting by Susan Heavey; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"
4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-economy-idUSKCN12S258	Strong economic report welcome boost for Clinton
column2: Trump calls it 'dismal'	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| MANCHESTER
column2: N.H.

column1: MANCHESTER
column2: N.H. A stronger-than-expected U.S. economic report on Friday came at a good time for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column3: although Republican contender Donald Trump's campaign blasted the numbers as ""dismal.""The Commerce Department reported that the economy grew at a 2.9 percent annual rate in the third quarter
column4: its fastest pace in two years and higher than the expected 2.6 percent
column5: thanks to a surge in exports and a rebound in investment. With just 11 days to go before the Nov. 8 election
column6: the report bolstered Clinton
column7: who has positioned herself as the best candidate to continue years of economic expansion under President Barack Obama.More Americans say jobs and the economy are their No.1 priority when they decide who to vote for than any other issue.Trump argues that as a successful businessman and political outsider
column8: he is the best person to take a new approach to rebuilding an economy that has sent too many jobs overseas and left many Americans struggling to find decent jobs.His campaign said the figures are still not good enough.""America can do better than the modest growth of 2.9 percent recorded for the 3rd quarter and the dismal growth of 1.5 percent for the past year

column1: Growth hasn't risen above 3 percent for a full year in any year of the Obama presidency
column2: he said.While many voters do not follow economic indicators closely
column3: outside experts said the release was still a good one for Clinton. She is seeking to solidify her lead in opinion polls as the Democratic Party works to win as many seats as possible in the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives
column4: where Republicans now control majorities.""Today's release will likely improve the perception of economic conditions in the U.S. and slightly increase the odds of a Democratic president remaining in the White House
column5: said Brian Schaitkin
column6: senior economist at the Conference Board.

column1: Clinton's camp said Friday's report showed ""real progress"" since Obama took office in 2009
column2: when the country was struggling to emerge from economic recession.""With more than 15 million jobs created since early 2010 and real median incomes growing more than 5 percent last year
column3: it's clear we've made real progress coming back from the crisis
column4: Clinton senior policy advisor Jacob Leibenluft said in a statement.But he added that there is still more that can be done.Clinton was campaigning on Friday in Iowa
column5: where polls show she and Trump running neck-and-neck
column6: and in Michigan
column7: a traditionally Democratic state hit hard by the movement offshore of many formerly well-paying American manufacturing jobs.

column1: Trump was holding rallies in Iowa as well as in another closely contested swing state
column2: New Hampshire
column3: and in Maine
column4: where his campaign sees a chance to grab one of four electoral votes.In the last weeks of the campaign
column5: Clinton has dramatically widened her advantage over Trump in ad spending
column6: amid questions over the celebrity businessman's pledge to contribute more than $100 million of his own money.He spent $56 million through the end of September
column9: according to filings.  Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway said on Fox News reports that the candidate has stopped putting his own money into his campaign are not true. ""He has said publicly many times he is in for $100 million and he is happy to invest in his campaign
column10: she said.  (Additional reporting by Doina Chiacu and Patricia Zengerle in Washington; Writing by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Alistair Bell)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN12S249	Trump seeks to boost presidential bid with $10 million infusion: reports	"
WASHINGTON Donald Trump has given $10 million of his personal money to his presidential campaign in an effort to boost his White House bid 11 days before the Nov. 8 election
column2: according to media reports. The Wall Street Journal
column3: citing two advisers
column4: said the Republican presidential nominee wired the money on Friday morning. A Fox News reporter said Trump told him he would give $10 million to the campaign on Friday.

column1: (Reporting by Susan Heavey; Editing by Doina Chiacu)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-jersey-bridgegate-idUSKCN12S22Q	New Jersey's 'Bridgegate' defendants executed 'vicious' scheme: prosecutor	"
By Joseph Ax
| NEWARK
column2: N.J.

column1: NEWARK
column2: N.J. Two former allies of New Jersey Governor Chris Christie deliberately closed access lanes to the George Washington Bridge in a ""vicious"" and unlawful political revenge scheme
column3: a federal prosecutor said on Friday at the close of their criminal trial.Bridget Kelly
column4: the governor's former deputy chief of staff
column5: and Bill Baroni
column6: the former deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
column7: abused their power to create a massive traffic jam in order to punish a local mayor for failing to back Christie's re-election campaign
column8: Assistant U.S. Attorney Lee Cortes told jurors in Newark
column9: New Jersey.""As cruel and callous as that scheme was
column10: what makes it unlawful was that they misused government resources to carry it out
column11: Cortes said in closing arguments at federal court in Newark
column12: New Jersey.Baroni's lawyer is expected to deliver his closing argument later on Friday.The Port Authority operates the George Washington Bridge
column13: said by the agency to be the world's busiest.

column1: Kelly and Baroni are charged with fraud
column2: conspiracy and depriving residents of Fort Lee
column3: New Jersey
column4: of their civil rights. Former Port Authority executive David Wildstein has pleaded guilty and appeared as the government's star witness.Christie has not been charged and has steadfastly denied any advance knowledge of the plan. But Wildstein
column5: Baroni and Kelly all testified that they told the governor some details about the lane closures either beforehand or while they were occurring. The so-called ""Bridgegate"" scandal tarnished Christie's national reputation
column6: damaging his unsuccessful bid for the Republican presidential nomination. The trial has cast an unflattering light on Christie as a temperamental bully whose administration used the Port Authority to hand out favors

column1: Kelly and Baroni
column2: both of whom testified in their own defense
column3: said they were duped by Wildstein and his claim that the lane closures were part of a legitimate traffic study.But Cortes warned jurors not to be fooled by that ""preposterous"" assertion
column4: pointing to Kelly's now-infamous email to Wildstein in which she wrote
column5: ""Time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee
column6: as evidence of her guilt.

column1: During his closing argument
column2: Cortes showed jurors numerous messages sent among Kelly
column3: Wildstein and Baroni suggesting they deliberately ignored Fort Lee Mayor Mark Sokolich's desperate pleas for help as the gridlock became untenable
column4: delaying first responders and stranding school buses for hours.At one point
column5: Wildstein told Baroni that his response to Sokolich should be ""radio silence."" (Reporting by Joseph Ax; Editing by Tom Brown)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-biden-idUSKCN12S1IC	Biden tops Clinton list for U.S. secretary of state: reports	"
WASHINGTON Vice President Joe Biden tops a short list for secretary of state that is being compiled by the transition team of Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column2: two media outlets reported.Politico on Thursday night cited an unidentified source as saying Clinton and her aides were discussing how to approach Biden about the post
column3: should she win the Nov. 8 presidential election.Most national opinion polls show Clinton
column4: who served as President Barack Obama's first secretary of state
column5: leading Republican Donald Trump in the race for the White House.Biden became a respected voice on foreign policy during his 36 years in the U.S. Senate
column6: where he was chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and at one point served alongside Clinton
column7: when she was a senator from New York.""He'd be great
column8: and they are spending a lot of time figuring out the best way to try to persuade him to do it if she wins
column9: the source familiar with Clinton's transition planning told Politico.

column1: NBC News later confirmed that Biden was under consideration for the job of top U.S. diplomat.Biden
column2: of Delaware
column3: had considered running for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2016. He has campaigned vigorously for Clinton in her race against Trump
column4: a New York real estate tycoon and former reality television personality who has never run for office.

column1: The vice president said at a campaign event for Clinton in Pennsylvania this week that he is frequently asked whether he wished he had been debating Trump
column2: who has insulted women
column3: Muslims and immigrants and thumbed his nose at political norms.""No
column4: I wish we were in high school. I could take him behind the gym. That's what I wish
column5: Biden said
column6: prompting a similarly pugilistic retort from Trump a couple of days later.

column1: In excepts from an interview released from CBS' Sunday program ""Face the Nation
column2: Biden made it clear he wanted to continue his public service.""I'm not going away. I'm
column3: you know
column4: everything from this issue of violence against women
column5: to income inequality
column6: to the cancer moonshot
column7: I'm gonna devote the rest of my life to this.""  (Writing by Doina Chiacu; Editing by Paul Simao)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-finland-idUSKCN12S1AX	Ex-Miss Finland says Trump groped her	"

HELSINKI A former Miss Finland has accused U.S. presidential candidate Donald Trump of groping her in 2006 when she was representing the country in the Miss Universe beauty contest.Ninni Laaksonen told the Ilta-Sanomat newspaper that the  Republican presidential nominee had grabbed her behind before she appeared on a television show in New York with other contestants.""He really grabbed my butt. I don't think anybody saw it but I flinched and thought: 'What is happening?'
column2: Laaksonen was quoted as saying in the newspaper.

column1: The accusation follows a stream of allegations of inappropriate conduct by Trump from other women in the United States which have put pressure on his campaign as he trails in  opinion polls ahead of the Nov. 8 election. Trump has denied the accusations.Laaksonen could not be reached for comment on Friday.
(Reporting by Jussi Rosendahl; Editing by Angus MacSwan)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-russia-poll-idUSKCN12S13Q	Most Republicans believe Russia is meddling in U.S. election: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Alana Wise
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Most Republicans believe Russia is attempting to influence the U.S. presidential election
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll
column3: despite comments by the party's nominee
column4: Donald Trump
column5: downplaying the possibility.Some 55 percent of U.S. adults
column6: including 51 percent of Republicans and 65 percent of Democrats
column7: said they thought Russia was trying to tip the scales in the Nov. 8 presidential election
column8: according to the survey. Most American adults - 62 percent of Democrats and 48 percent of Republicans - think Putin is supporting Trump for the White House
column9: the poll found.Some 71 percent of those who suspect Russia of meddling believe Moscow is doing so through the recent hacks of Democratic emails
column10: according to the Oct. 18-24 survey. But 57 percent of those who suspect Russian interference also believe Trump has ""no involvement in Russia's release of unflattering information"" on his Democratic rival
column11: Hillary Clinton.The U.S. government has accused Russia of a campaign of cyber attacks targeting the Democratic Party that has led to the release of thousands of illegally obtained emails
column12: revealing the sometimes unflattering inner workings of the party

column1: Clinton has said she believes the Kremlin is trying to help Trump
column2: calling her rival a ""puppet"" of the Russian leader. Trump has declined to implicate the country in any wrongdoing.""I don't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the (Democratic National Committee)
column3: Trump said during the first presidential debate last month. He suggested the culprit could be anyone from Russia
column4: to China or even ""a 400-pound person lying in bed.""Russia has denied it sponsors or encourages hacking activity. Russian President Vladimir Putin accused U.S. politicians on Thursday of whipping up ""hysteria"" about a nonexistent threat in order to distract voters.

column1: Putin
column2: who has described Trump as ""very talented
column3: said on Thursday the New York businessman ""behaves extravagantly"" to ""get through to voters' hearts."" Trump has said he is not close with Putin
column4: but has also said he believes the Russian president is a stronger leader than U.S. President Barack Obama.

column1: Already chilly relations between the United States and Russia have deteriorated over disagreements over the conflicts in Ukraine and Syria. U.S. officials say U.S. agencies have concluded that two Russian intelligence agencies - the military's GRU and the civilian foreign intelligence agency
column2: the FSB - are behind U.S. political hacking
column3: particularly that directed against Democratic Party organizations and individuals.The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted online in English
column4: and included 2
column5: 008 American adults. It had a credibility interval
column6: a measure of accuracy
column7: of 3 percentage points. (Additional reporting by Yara Bayoumy; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
